stories.text:
After having sold my small business and having landed a well paying job, I find myself with some money to start saving for the first time in my adult life.

I'm in my late 20s, in a long term relationship, no kids, no money I can count on from my parents, and have ~70K sitting idle in my bank account. My goal is to preserve it, defend against inflation, and in general being responsible with it.

I could open a savings account and let the bank take care of it, but it looks to me that managing savings is not rocket science: ETF / index fund should do the trick. And I could save in fees. Also, I'd like to learn.

Am I right? How can I learn how to manage my finances? What tools to use, what simple strategies to pursue, and whatnot. Tried to Google it / find YT videos but it's all a huge content marketing mess. Everyone pitching "how to retire early" or "how to make money in the stock market". I'm not interested: I just want to be proactive and prepared with my personal finances, so that in 10 years from now I can buy a house (not interested in taking a mortgage now: I value flexibility more) and take care of my potential future family.

Would love to hear your strategies and your advice on how I can learn.
stories.title: Ask HN: How to Invest Savings?

stories.text:
We've had a challenge asked of us. Re-creating a PDF Catalogue that has around 530 pages (about 1300 products) into a digital form.

Logic being they have to pay and spend a lot of time to create a PDF and then a digital version (basically a PDF Viewer which has some interactivity) and then reformat the data to import the product into an ordering tool.

By consolidating these steps, we could import it into the ordering tool (or a pre-processor which runs along side the ordering tool) and "spit out" the relevant versions. However, I don't think it's realistic to generate a PDF version programmatically, so we may still have to setup a PDF generated via data using InDesign (not a disaster) but then we have the challenge of recreating a digital catalogue on the web.

They can't lose the ability to print the "digital catalogue" which restricts us, I believe.

Any ideas / anyone seen anything in the wild that works well?

EDIT: Worth saying, the ordering tool is built in NET Core.
stories.title: Ask HN: Replacing PDF Catalogue with just digital?
DeLorean returns with 300-mile Taycan rival for 2024

stories.text:
Hi HN:

Just reaching out to the hn community to see if anyone might be able to point me to a paying coding gig, and also provide a small advance in order to obtain a reasonable laptop to perform the work.

I asked for help here last week, and a number of people sent me emergency food money. I have been rationing this money and should be okay for food until my SNAP food benefits renew this coming weekend. I am living unsheltered, and am seeking to reach a point where I can code full time and build a financial base. I live in the countryside where it's warm, but there are limited resources here.

I do need basic items like a bicycle, a tent, and a membership at the local coworking space. But, most important perhaps is to obtain a laptop, and a paying project to earn the laptop. Does anyone in the community have a spare laptop (min. 8GB RAM/SSD) or can anyone possibly hire me for coding to pay off a new laptop? I am proficient in most phases of web development and am a seasoned software developer who burned out a few years ago. Seeking to start coding professionally again and establish a low-stress coding routine. I am in my 40's in the USA.

Once I am up and running with needed basics, I can then seek work online, then eventually seek an interview for a ft/permanent position. Just problem solving one problem at a time.

If you can help, can you email me at hackernewscontactmail at gmail? Thank you.
stories.title: Ask HN: Work project for laptop and other basics
Image of a genome autosuspends you from Twitter
US urban planners cannot wholly undo sprawl
